entry.title: Re: How to update a source of an UNION in a graphical view
entry.content:
Hi Xavi, 

I simulated the issue and yes, graphical views behave this way. 

Initially there is the Line Currency field from the other source. But UNION requires to have all fields defined, this is mandatory when working with UNIONs in a SQL view (I work mostly with SQL views). Therefore I would say, that in case you add a new field, the graphical UNION expects that all sources and all source fields are 1:1 and mapped already (like in SQL view), therefore any new fields is automatically added and mapped.
In your case, the Line Currency should already exist in the fist source at least as a dummy ('DUM' AS "Line Currency"). I would say, that the graphical UNION should not allow creating fields from unmapped sources in the first place, but I guess this is wanted thus working as designed.

My suggestion would be to create dummy fields in the sources, same approach as SQL view.

 

Martin

entry.title: Hedonic Pricing: What Do Investors Pay For?
entry.content:
Executive summary
Investors do not primarily pay for short-term margin spikes or isolated growth initiatives.  Instead, over a 35-year horizon, the market has consistently rewarded one thing above all else: persistency.  This is the term Goldman Sachs attaches to the capital structure discipline, specifically leverage (Assets/Equity).  We find that leverage explains the majority of the variation in Home Depot’s Market Cap / Equity, our proxy for the Price/Book ratio.  This finding closely replicates Goldman Sachs’ famous analysis of what markets pay for, but applies to a single company and validates using long-horizon time-series data. Profitability and efficiency matter — but they come second.

This note describes our findings in three simple blocks:

  • data preparation and transformation
  • results and interpretation
  • what it means for Home Depot and investors.

 

1. Data preparation: looking at Home Depot the way markets do

This analysis starts from a simple premise:

If we want to understand how investors value Home Depot, we must model Home Depot the way investors observe it.

We assembled 144 quarters (1990–2025 YTD) of data covering both market valuation metrics (P/B ratio, Market Cap, Enterprise Value) and accounting fundamentals (assets, equity, leverage, margins, asset turnover).

This is important: unlike cross-sectional studies across many firms, this model is time-series for a single company. We are not asking why Home Depot is valued differently than Lowe’s.  We are asking a more precise question:

What has historically driven changes in Home Depot’s valuation over time?

Log transformations: elasticity, not levels

All core variables are expressed in logarithmic form. This is essential for interpretation:

  • Coefficients become elasticities
  • Relationships become scale-free
  • Long-term growth dynamics dominate short-term noise

In plain English: we are modeling percentage changes investors respond to, not absolute dollar movements.

The dependent (predicted) variable is the

ln(Market Cap / Equity), a proxy for the P/B ratio, directly links market valuation to balance-sheet fundamentals — exactly how long-term equity investors think.

Three independent (predictor) variables are

Leverage = (Assets - Goodwill) / Stockholders Equity where we specifically remove Goodwill to account for “tangible leverage” only,

Net Margin = Net Income / Revenue, 

Turnover = Revenue / (Assets - Goodwill) here too, assets are net of goodwill for "tangible turnover."

In one quarter, Home Depot reported negative net income. In 9 quarters the company reported negative equity - initially in 2019 as a result of the adoption of the FASB ASU No. 2016-02, "Leases (Topic 842)".  This is why the lines in the plot below exhibit discontinuities: natural logarithm of a negative number is undefined.

In log terms, valuation and operating fundamentals move in clear and persistent co-movement over time.  Sustained multiple expansion coincides with rising operating efficiency, greater leverage capacity, and improving margins, while periods of valuation compression align with broad-based fundamental deterioration.  Valuation itself behaves as a slow-moving state variable, reflecting investors’ long-run assessment of economic capacity, whereas operating metrics adjust at higher frequency around that state.  Even during externally imposed disruptions—such as recessions and market panics—temporary dislocations give way to re-convergence, underscoring that market multiples are ultimately disciplined by fundamentals rather than driven by sentiment alone.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This systematic co-movement directly motivates a hedonic valuation, in which observed market multiples are modeled as the equilibrium price investors assign to distinct operating characteristics rather than as standalone time-series outcomes.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

2. The hedonic pricing regression: what explains Home Depot's valuation?

Conceptually, the model mirrors the DuPont identity, which decomposes Return on Equity into three elements:

  • Leverage (Assets / Equity)
  • Profitability (Net Margin)
  • Efficiency (Asset Turnover)

Our model - with the log-transformed data - is:

To accommodate periods of negative net margin and negative stockholders’ equity, we introduced dummy variables that flag sign changes (0 for positive values, 1 for negative).  The inclusion of dummy variables allows the model to accommodate sign changes without materially altering coefficient magnitudes or inference. 

The regression, run in R Studio, produced a formula where most coefficients are statistically significant at the 5% level (p<0.05).  The ln_net_margin variable returned a p-value of 0.0744, indicating a 7.4% probability of observing this result (or one more extreme) if there were actually no relationship between ln_net_margin and ln_mktcap_over_equity.

We drop the decimals:

Here is the most intuitive interpretation of the model’s coefficients and log-terms: elasticity. These bars represent standardized coefficients, not raw elasticities, and are intended for relative magnitude and intuition, not literal percentage translation.


 

Home Depot’s valuation is most sensitive to changes in asset turnover, indicating that improvements in capital efficiency drive market multiples more powerfully than margin expansion alone.

In raw log terms, leverage can be interpreted as follows: a 1% increase in leverage increases Market Cap / Equity by approximately 1%.

Net margins exhibit a comparatively modest elasticity, suggesting that accounting profitability, while important, does not independently command valuation premiums.

Taken together, the results align closely with how long-term equity investors think: sustainable valuation expansion is rooted in efficient deployment of capital, not short-term margin optimization.

 

The key result: persistency dominates

The model has R2 of 94.05% and Adjusted R2 of 93.91%.  If we decompose the individual predictors’ contribution to this explained variance in Market Cap/Equity, the key conclusion emerges:

Visually, this is striking: the largest block by far is leverage. Most of what investors paid for Home Depot over 35 years is captured by three variables of which Leverage is the most significant. This is what Goldman Sachs found in their panel data analysis calling the hedonic pricing element persistency.

Persistency, in Goldman’s framework, means:

  • Stable capital structure
  • Predictable balance-sheet scaling
  • Consistency in how equity is multiplied into assets and cash flows

What we have done here is replicate that insight, but:

  • For one company
  • Using 35 years of quarterly data
  • With a fully transparent regression framework

The alignment is almost exact.

Notably, the model contains no explicit time trends, macroeconomic variables, or sentiment indicators—yet it explains over 94% of valuation variation, underscoring how consistently markets price the same economic fundamentals.

In Home Depot’s case, leverage alone explains roughly two-thirds of the market’s valuation signal. Profitability matters — but it is secondary, less persistent, and less trusted by investors as a long-term signal.

Both actual and predicted series represent the log market-cap-to-equity multiple where

The chart shows that a simple three-variable hedonic model tracks Home Depot’s valuation remarkably well over more than three decades. Even though the model has no awareness of time, cycles, or sentiment, its predicted valuation closely follows the actual market valuation across multiple regimes. Deviations between the two lines are concentrated in periods of market stress or speculative excess, while long-run trends are captured cleanly.

In other words, investors consistently price the same economic fundamentals, though they might temporarily lose discipline during panics and recessions.

This directly supports the executive intuition captured in the quote by Dilip Shanghvi, the founder and CEO of Sun Pharmaceuticals:

“I will never risk capital; but I will risk profit.”

Markets agree.

 

3. How solid is our model? Is it "too clean"?

No serious business model should avoid this question.

Residual behavior (what we checked)

We explicitly reviewed:

  • Residual distribution
  • Residuals vs. fitted values
  • Time clustering during stress periods

 

 


 


 

With F-statistics 684.4 on 3 and 130 degrees of freedom and p-value < 2.2 x 10-16, the model is structurally sound, though markets still panic occasionally — and then revert.

That is exactly what we would expect from real investors.

What do residuals tell us

Residuals widen during periods of macro-financial stress, including the Global Financial Crisis, COVID, and the post-2022 rate shock. This is expected: markets temporarily price fear, liquidity constraints, and narrative risk beyond firm-level fundamentals.

Outside stress regimes, residuals oscillate tightly around zero with no persistent bias. Deviations cluster in time rather than by sign, indicating regime effects rather than model misspecification. Overvaluation episodes—most notably the late 1990s—mean-revert as market discipline reasserts itself.

Bottom line: the model “fails” when markets panic — and reliably re-anchors valuation once sentiment normalizes.

 

*   *   *

 

So, what does this actually mean for Home Depot?

Insight #1: capital discipline is the valuation anchor

Home Depot’s high valuation multiple is not fragile.  It is anchored in:

  • Consistent leverage
  • Predictable scaling of equity
  • Transparent capital return policy

Any unexpected shift in capital structure — aggressive deleveraging or sudden debt expansion — would matter far more to valuation than a bad margin quarter.

Insight #2: profitability matters — but only if it is repeatable

Operational improvements (margin, turnover, ROA) explain about one quarter of valuation variation.  That is meaningful — but markets discount one-off wins.  Investors prefer:

  • Incremental improvements
  • Predictable execution
  • Fewer surprises

Spectacular quarters impress analysts. Consistent ones move valuation.

Insight #3: macro matters less than headlines suggest

Despite constant focus on rates, housing cycles, and sentiment, macro variables explain only a single-digit share of long-term valuation variation.  Home Depot’s valuation history is fundamentally a company-driven story, not a macro-driven one.

Once full-year 2025 financials are available, we will:

  • Re-estimate the model
  • Test coefficient stability
  • Re-evaluate valuation implications under the new regime and compare/contrast the hedonic pricing model with the traditional DCF valuation model

If history is any guide, the conclusion is unlikely to change — but the path may.

 

Final thought

Markets are often accused of being short-term and irrational. Over 35 years of Home Depot data suggests the opposite.

Investors are remarkably consistent in what they reward.

They pay for persistency.

entry.title: CrystalDecisions.Web Version 13.0.3500.0 missing in Crystal Reports Runtime / CR for Visual Studio
entry.content:
I am troubleshooting a legacy Windows Forms application that uses SAP Crystal Reports. The application fails when running reports with the following error:

Could not load file or assembly ‘CrystalDecisions.Web, Version=13.0.3500.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=692fbea5521e1304’

Environment details:

  • Windows Server and Windows 11 Enterprise multi session (Azure Virtual Desktop)

  • .NET Framework 4.8

  • Crystal Reports Runtime 13.0.32 installed

  • ODBC Driver 17 for SQL Server configured and tested successfully

  • SQL connectivity confirmed

What we have tried:

  • Installed Crystal Reports Runtime 13.0.32 (vendor confirmed this is the correct version)

  • Reproduced the issue consistently across multiple clean environments

  • Extracted and reviewed the Crystal Reports for Visual Studio SP19 install package

  • Verified that CrystalDecisions.Web.dll is not included in the runtime or CR for Visual Studio packages

  • Confirmed this is not an ODBC or SQL authentication issue

The application appears to be explicitly requesting:

CrystalDecisions.Web.dll Assembly version: 13.0.3500.0

However, SAP no longer seems to ship this assembly in current or legacy Crystal Reports runtime or developer distributions.

Questions:

  1. Is CrystalDecisions.Web.dll 13.0.3500.0 still supported or distributed by SAP?

  2. If so, which Crystal Reports package or SDK includes this assembly?

  3. If not, is there a recommended approach for legacy desktop applications that reference CrystalDecisions.Web?

  4. Is this assembly deprecated, and should applications be rebuilt to remove the dependency?

Any guidance on sourcing this assembly or confirming its deprecation would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Error in the consumption data transfer flow to the CC
entry.content:
Hello everyone,
I’d like to share a problem and check if any of you have experienced this before and have something to share.

We have a flow that consumes the CC API/Webservice (chargeableItemCharging) for the creation of CITs. We’ve always used it normally and never had issues. Let me explain how it works: there is an ABAP program that consumes data from BI, the XML is assembled in ABAP(on XI), and it arrives ready at CPI, which forwards it to CC so that the consumption pricing and their creation in ConvergentInvoice (CI) can be carried out. We store the response message to keep track of any errors that may occur during these transmissions.

Well, recently we added some new fields to the Chargeable Item Class that we use for this operation, and we started receiving the error “PART_BOUNDARY_NOT_FOUND” for some large data packages (1000 consumptions) that we process. After doing some research about the error, it seems to be related to the XML assembly and not to CC. I found SAP Note #821379 in a post that mentioned the same error, but since it is a VERY old note, I decided to share the scenario with you before applying it to understand if it makes sense.

Below is an image of the response we received on ABAP debug:

Thank you in advance for your time!

entry.title: Stock transport order API has no ability to change ship to address
entry.content:
The Stock transport order API has no ability to change ship to address.  We have a business need to transfer materials from one plant to another plant (representing an Amazon Distribution Center).  The addresses of the specific Amazon Distribution Centers are dynamic in nature.  We would like the ability to update the ship to address (seems to be defaulted to the receiving plant address) when creating the STO via the API.  Please advise.  This functionality is available via the UI.  


--- Steps to Reproduce ---

This API from the business accelerator has no fields for address input. 




------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Stock transport order API has no ability to change sh...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the Stock Transport Order (STO) API – CE_STOCKTRANSPORTORDER_0001 is working as designed.

Why the Ship-To Address Cannot Be Changed via API

  • In S/4HANA Cloud, an STO is a plant-to-plant logistics document.

  • The Ship-To address is always derived from the receiving plant’s address (plant master data).

  • The public API does not expose address fields for STO creation because:

    • Allowing free-form or dynamic addresses would break core logistics and inventory valuation logic

    • STOs are tightly coupled with plant determination, stock postings, and follow-on documents

  • Therefore, changing the Ship-To address via API is intentionally restricted.

 This is standard product behavior, not a technical gap or API defect.

 

Why It Works in the UI but Not in the API

  •  the system may allow temporary/manual address adjustments (for example, for output or delivery purposes).

  • However:

    • These changes do not change the underlying plant determination

    • The API strictly follows the business object contract and does not support such overrides

The Stock Transport Order API does not support changing the Ship-To address because, in S/4HANA Cloud, STOs are strictly plant-to-plant documents. The Ship-To address is always derived from the receiving plant master data. While the UI may allow limited manual adjustments, this is not exposed in the public API by design.

For dynamic Amazon Distribution Center addresses, SAP recommends modeling each DC as a separate plant or using a different business process (such as customer or intercompany scenarios) that supports dynamic addresses via API.

 

Thank you

entry.title: Re: Can the cost center cost allocation cycle rule select...
entry.content:
Hello @frezhang 

Thank you for your question

 

To answer your question on “if this is a missing configuration”. The answer is no. You not finding the Actual Activity is because it is not offered as a variable portion type. The reason is described in KBA 3338660.

However, for Actual allocation, the system provides some Variable Portion Types that are typically limited to items like:

  • Actual amounts. This covers your transactional, local and group currency
  • Actual Quantities
  • Statistical Key Figures

So, you will only see those mentioned and not Actual Activity. KBA 3407708 describes how you can use it.

In public cloud you can workaround this depending on what you require:

1. If your driver is an activity quantity, then you should use SKF-Actual. You can do this by:

  • Creating an SKF that represents the activity driver (which could be machine hours, labour hours, etc.) and post actual SKF quantities.
  • As a Variable Portion Type in the allocation cycle ensure you use SKF- Actual

2. If you truly need activity type-based allocation, then use Activity Allocation apps or process, not universal Allocation variable portions to achieve that goal. Activity type logic is handled in the activity allocation framework and not as a tracing factor in Manage Allocation.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Check data and specify void reason code INTERCOMPANY...
entry.content:
Good day @AreebaZakir 

Thank you for your question

From your screenshot I can see you are in GUI and not a public cloud Fiori flow.

That said, the message you have on your screen means the system will only allow you to cancel or reverse your task if you enter the mandatory void reason code. In other words, you have to specify a legal or compliance reason for cancelling the document. Once you have completed this, the system will unblock the reversal.

If you are using the public cloud, ensure:

  • You use Reverse Journal Entries or Manage Journal Entries app, find the entry you wish to reverse.

  • Then maintain your reversal reason in the appointed dialog. If the system prompts for Void Reason Code, open the value help and select the correct reason.

  • Should your tenant not have void reason code list, then you do not have the necessary configuration for the reason code. You can maintain this in public cloud through the Central Business Configuration.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Delete Completed item of service order
entry.content:
Good day @Lily16 

Thank you for your question

Based on your screenshot, your item 30 is completed and you normally cannot delete it in the sense of removing it from the PO. In the public cloud, once GR, invoice exit, the system keeps the audit trail. However, what you can do is reverse the GR and invoice first and then set the item to Deleted or close it correctly.

The summary on how to proceed is to:

  • Post a return for the GR if you received goods, and
  • Post a credit memo for the invoice, then
  • Leave your PO item as completed for traceability.

Please note that this process does not erase history. Rather it blocks further processing and removes it from your operational flow lists.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Asking for CDS View for Free Form Payment App (F2564)

I am not aware of any released CDS view for payment request. See: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/031c345485b84c8c94265be9ef61d3a8/67a84bce46254a6c840a9eb873a158e4.html?locale=en-US for more details.

I suggest you read the payment request data through released APIs rather than direct CDS access. You can search for payment Request in the Business Accelerator Hub, filter for public cloud Edition, then use the released API to extract the payment request data and persist it to your extension. You may also consume it directly in your integration.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Legacy Data Transfer - Security Positions
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog primarily outlines the process of transferring legacy data of security positions (bond, stock, investment certificate, etc.) from external systems into the Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) module, as a critical step in initial go-live data migration. The process is illustrated using an example of bond issuance in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Foundational Knowledge

To fully engage with the content ahead, familiarity with the following foundational concepts is recommended:

  • The position components constitute the financial position of an interest rate instrument – refer to blog Position Changes and Postings Across the Life of an Interest Rate Instrument or relevant SAP held documents (e.g. Position Components) for detailed context.
  • How accrual of interest income or expenses works – refer to blog Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure or SAP help document Accrual/Deferral of Expenses and Revenues detailed context.

The above-referenced blogs use OTC money market instrument for illustration, but the underlying principles are similar in essence.

It is also recommended reading the blog Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions, which may help you gain insights into the differences between OTC transactions’ legacy data transfer and security positions’ legacy data transfer.

Migration of Transactions (?)

A frequently asked question is whether security transactions need to be imported into SAP TRM and how to handle them?

Actually, there is no need to import security transactions. Unlike OTC transactions— which serve as the core "carrier" (referred to as a differentiation term in SAP TRM terminology) for position management purpose and must be imported into the system—security positions are the result of the combined effect of multiple purchase/placement transactions, sale/redemption transactions, valuations, and other business transactions. Therefore, for data migration, it is sufficient to import the position of a specific security class in a given security account (disregarding discussion of other differentiation terms here) as of the cut-off date. Furthermore, the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit does not provide a migration object for importing security transactions.

Creation of Master Data

Before importing the position data for security, two master data should be created: security class, security account.

Security Class

The specific steps for creating a security class are not elaborated on here. We assume the following security class has been created in SAP TRM.

Key elements of this security class:

  • Issue start: 01.10.2025
  • Issue end: 01.04.2026
  • Issuance currency: USD
  • Coupon rate: 3% (act/360)
  • Coupon frequency: every 2 months
  • Redemption structure: financial repayment

Simulate Cash flow (for position category “Liability”):

Security Account

The process of creating a security account (for issuance purpose) is omitted herein.

Enter Data of Position Indicator

Since the position indicator for security position can’t be generated through creation of security transaction (as aforementioned, security transaction creation is not required), you can use the app Enter Data of Security Position Indicators (app ID: TPM61A) to maintain the position indicator data for the security position.

In this example, we will always focus on valuation area 003 only, the details for legacy data transfer of other valuation areas are omitted although they are also needed.

Transfer Data of Security Position Indicators

With the app Transfer Data of Security Position Indicators (app ID: TPM61), you create the position indicator for the security class within the security account, and the subledger position indicator (for valuation area 003) is also created, based on the data maintained in TPM61A.

Log after successful execution of TPM61A:

Open app Manage Position Indicator (app ID: TPM57A) to check in the position indicator:

After the creation of position indicator, the security position value data should be then migrated, there are two parts for position value data of security:

  • Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions
  • Valuation Area-dependent Data of Security Positions

In this example, let’s assume that the go-live of TRM is planned at 01.01.2026, so the position values of this security class within the issuance security account as of 31.12.2025 should be migrated from position management and financial accounting perspectives.

Enter Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions

With app Enter Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions (app ID: TPM63A), you enter the valuation area-independent data of security positions for the position value date. You specify, for example, the nominal amount, purchase values, and capitalized costs in addition to the quantity information (units or nominal amounts).

This following table contains the data to be entered in TPM63A for this example:

Field

Data used in this example

Remark for the field

Position Value Date

31.12.2025

 

Company Code

1010

 

General Valuation Class

26

 

Security Class

BND_TEST_01

 

Securities Account

ISSUANCE

 

Position Currency

USD

 

Local Currency

EUR

In this example, the local currency of company code 1010 is EUR

Assets/Liabs Pos.

Liability Posit

Enter “Liability Posit” in the example since it is bond issuance.

Calculation Date

31.12.2025

 

Units

Blank

Used for unit-quoted security

Original Nominal Amount PC

Blank

Used for bonds with installment repayments (ABS/MBS)

Nominal Amount

100,000,000.00

Used for percentage-quoted security. Always enter positive value.

In this example, the nominal of the issued bond is 100M USD.

Nominal Currency

USD

 

Purchase Value in PC

-98,000,000.00

Enter positive value for asset position, enter negative value for liability position.

In this example, the bond is issued at 98% of its face value, so the purchase value is 98,000,000.00, with the discount amounting to 2,000,000.00 USD.

Purchase Value in LC

-83,456,800.00

In this example, the exchange rate USD/EUR as of the issuing date (01.10.2025) = 0.8516, 98,000,000.00*0.8516=83,456,800.00 EUR.

Costs in Pos.Crcy

12,000.00

In this example, the issuance cost for bond is 12,000.00 USD.

Cost in LC

10,219.20

12,000.00**0.8516=10,219.20 EUR.

Screen-shots of TPM63A:

Notes:

  • Not every available field of TPM63A are listed in the above table.
  • You may always find more comprehensive information from help document Enter Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions.
  • For legacy data transfer of OTC transactions, the position component purchase value can’t be specified in TPM63C, because it has been determined by the operational cash flow within the OTC transaction. However, for legacy data transfer of security positions, it is needed to specify the purchase value in TPM63A, because security transactions are not migrated.
  • In this example, the total unamortized discount as of issuing date = 2,000.000.00 + 12,000.00 = 2,012,000.00 USD.

Enter Valuation Area-Dependent Data of Security Positions

Now, let’s enter the valuation area-dependent position component values for this security position by using the app Enter Valuation Area-Dependent Data of Security Positions (app ID: TPM63B). Screen-shots:

Elaborate the data entered in TPM63B in below table:

Field

Data used in this example

Remark for the field

Position Value Date

31.12.2025

 

Company Code

1010

 

General Valuation Class

26

 

Valuation Area

003

 

Security Class

BND_TEST_01

 

Securities Account

ISSUANCE

 

Position Currency

USD

 

Valuation Currency

EUR

In this example, the valuation currency is EUR (=local currency of company code 1010)

Assets/Liabs Pos.

Liability Posit

Enter “Liability Posit” in the example since it is bond issuance.

Security Valuation in Position Currency

Blank

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

In this example, no security valuation should be migrated since issued bond is evaluated at historical cost (amortized cost).

Security Valuation in Valuation Currency

Blank

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

FX Valuation in Valuation Currency

180,021.60

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

In this example, this amount is the FX valuation recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the issued bond in the legacy system.

FX Valuation Costs in Valuation Currency

-21.6

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

In this example, this amount is the FX valuation for capitalized cost recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the issued bond in the legacy system.

Amortization in Position Currency

- 997,017.02

Positive value for positive amortization; Negative value for negative amortization.

In this example, this amount is the amortization amount in PC (part of the initial discount 2,012,000.00 USD) which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the issued bond in the legacy system.

Amortization in Valuation Currency

-850,021.40

In this example, this amount is the amortization amount in VC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Discount in PC

-1.014.982,98

Positive value for premium, negative value for discount, in case of liability position; Positive value for discount, negative value for premium, in case of asset position.

This is only needed when the amortization procedure of the position management procedure uses ‘gross method’ in SAP TRM; if amortization procedure uses ‘net method’, then there’s no need to enter value for these two fields of ‘Discount’ within TPM63B.

In this example, this amount is the remaining unamortized discount in PC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Discount in VC

-863.397.80

In this example, this amount is the remaining unamortized discount in VC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Accrual/deferral (1) in position currency

-258,333.33

Usually, enter positive value for accrual of income from investment, or deferral of expenses from issuance; enter negative value for accrual of expenses from issuance, or deferral of income from investment.

In this example, this amount is the balance of accrual account (liability) in PC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system, and the assumption is that SAP TRM use reset procedure for TPM44 accrual after go-live.

Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency

-219,531.66

In this example, this amount is the balance of accrual account (liability) in VC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Accrual/deferral with Reset

X

If this indicator is set, a reset business transaction for the transferred accruals/deferrals is generated additionally.

Reset Date

01.01.2026

If the reset date is not entered, the reset will occur on “position value date + 1”.

Notes: Not every available field of TPM63B are listed in the above table.

Initial Load of Position Values

After the data has been entered in TPM63A and TPM63B, use the app Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM63) to read legacy data you’ve entered in TPM63A and TPM63B, and transfer it to the position management of TRM for this security position.

There are 3 options for “Accounting Update”:

  • Do Not Update: choose this option if the accounting data is migrated via other means other than TRM (e.g. migrated the balances of position account, discount account, accrual account in general ledger accounting). No posting will be generated from TPM63 if this option is selected.
  • Update: choose this option and then TPM63 will generate accounting documents for legacy data transfer related business transactions, usually using update type DT_*; and the postings rely on the account determination setup for those update types.
  • Update Only for Reset Business Transactions: if you have migrated accounting data by other means only up to the transfer key date, and you would like to post the reset business transactions (for amortizations, valuations, or accruals/deferrals) through TPM63, you can choose this option.

In this example, we choose Update to illustrate the whole picture of postings.

Log for TPM63 run:

You can also check the posting log by clicking Logs and Messages, the screen-shot is omitted here. Instead, let’s use the T-accounts to illustrate the effects of postings generated from TPM63 run:

The bond payable, unamortized discount, and accrual account, all of the relevant balance sheet accounts have correctly reflected the balances which are equal to the legacy system’s data for this security position, in both of position currency and valuation currency. The Financial Statement of Position as of reporting date 31.12.2025 then can be properly prepared in SAP system.

In this example, the “gross method” is used for the amortization procedure. Therefore, the bond payable account reflects the face value of the issued bonds (100,000,000.00 USD / 84,980,000.00 EUR, reflecting the latest exchange rate 0.8498). From an accounting standpoint, the carrying amount of the security position (short-term liability) is calculated as the face value minus the unamortized discount (1,014,982.98 USD / 863,397.80 EUR), resulting in 98,985,017.02 USD / 84,116,602.20 EUR.

You may wonder why accrual is reset on 01.01.2026—this is to ensure the accuracy of interest expenses for the month of January 2026 under the reset procedure of TPM44. For a detailed explanation of the rationale, please refer to the blog Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions, which elaborates on the underlying reasons. While this blog uses an example of an investment OTC transaction, the core logic is consistent with the security position scenario, so we will not repeat the details here. This same blog also covers the handling of legacy data transfer for the difference procedure of TPM44, which requires assigning additional update types in configuration activity 104457 “Assign Additional Update Types for Difference Procedure”, we will not elaborate further on this configuration step and process of difference procedure either.

Check the position flows in TPM13:

Check the position component values in TPM12 as of 31.12.2025:

Illustrate the calculation logic of position component values in the following manner:

This blog has essentially come to a close. In the above example, we assumed that the legacy system and SAP TRM adopt the same calculation and posting logic for position components, enabling direct one-to-one mapping during legacy data migration. However, this is not always the case in practice—there are usually some discrepancies between the two systems to varying degrees. How to address these discrepancies? Below are several alternative approaches for reference:

  • Treat the legacy security businesses as if they had been processed in SAP TRM from their inceptions, simulate the position component values as of the cut-off date in SAP TRM and use these simulated values as the “benchmark”. Any discrepancies between these values and those from the legacy system are adjusted in the financial statements as of the cut-off date, classified as accounting estimate changes or accounting error corrections, etc. This approach requires specific confirmation from the auditors.
  • Accept the discrepancies between the legacy system and SAP TRM, and directly proceed with subsequent processing in accordance with SAP TRM logic. However, the results of subsequent measurement and derecognition after system go-live (e.g., amortization, foreign exchange valuation, realized gain/loss) may be inconsistent with those generated by the legacy system. This approach requires specific confirmation from the auditors.
  • Modify the configuration in SAP TRM to align or approximate its processing logic with that of the legacy system. This approach is particularly applicable when the legacy security businesses were previously managed also in the TRM module of SAP ECC or S/4HANA On-Premise and now needs to be migrated to the TRM module of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for continued management. In such cases, you can adjust the TRM configuration in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to make it consistent or closely aligned with the configuration in the former system.

Additional Notes

  • You may always find more comprehensive information from help document Legacy Data Transfer.
  • In the example above, the issuance cost 12,000.000 USD is managed in a standalone composition component ‘capitalized costs’, which requires additional configuration modifications, the details are omitted herein.
  • Which DT_* update types are invoked for TPM63 is specified in configuration activity 106944 “Assign Update Types for Legacy Data Transfer”. Sample configuration:
  • This blog only outlines certain means and posting patterns associated with legacy data transfer; such postings can vary based on specific business requirements and can be implemented with the various flexibilities offered by the SAP system.
  • App Reverse Transfer of Security Position Indicator (app ID: TPM62) is used to reverse the transfer done by TPM61.
  • App Reverse Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM64) is used to reverse results from TPM63.

entry.title: Re: Datasphere: Hiding dimensions used for filtering from...
entry.content:
Hi Dimitar, 

in BW you mean that you can create a sub-query as filter, or you mean when creating the query, you can use global filter which is not visible for the user, but the characteristics / info-object has to be in the Multi, or Cube, or aDSO or openODS (could also be a field-based). But you could not hide the Info-object in the provider self. 

I do understand your point. I run into the very same issue, with BW however as well. Always to explain the difference of an NAV/DIS attribute and transactional data. Well very same in DSP, just that in DSP there is no Query object. You have only the provider level (BW-like). So no, you cannot filter and hide a dimension. You can use a filter in a Story (script it or create it, but only in Story not when you include the model/exposed view).

Suggestion. Materialize the MAT_SALES__0VENDOR in the Model-View (FACT level) and create a parameter, wich you consume via the AM. In the AM you would not provide MAT_SALES__0VENDOR, but still can filter on it via the parameter.

Martin

entry.title: Re: Datasphere: Hiding dimensions used for filtering from...
entry.content: Hi Martin. The point I was trying to make in BW, is that you can define a filter on MAT_SALES_0VENDOR without having it in the query structure nor as a free characteristic. Input Parameter is not an option since this Fact View is used for different reports where not every one of them uses the same prompt and consequently has a filter on  MAT_SALES__0VENDOR

entry.title: Re: Datasphere: Hiding dimensions used for filtering from...
entry.content: I see. In BW you still have to have the info object in the provider. In DSP you do not have a Query object, only Provider. Then you will need to copy the model-view, create a parameter and use it in AM. Or if your MAT_SALES__0VENDOR (NAV attr) is static, create kind of lookup-table and have it filtered in the view without parameter and create AMs as Query-Views. Martin

entry.title: Data Lakes Files physical storage and Object Store in Datasphere & BDC context
entry.content:
Greetings SAP experts!

For some time I am trying to understand some concepts in regards to the Object Store and Data Lake Files physical storage in Datasphere & BDC context.

First I will start with naming the main service components of the SAP HANA Cloud that you can subscribe in SAP BTP:

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database
  • SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake further formed from:
    • Data Lake Files
    • Data Lake Relational Engine

https://help.sap.com/docs/hana-cloud/sap-hana-cloud-getting-started-guide/sap-hana-cloud-components

Now let's start with SAP Datasphere

When we have a Customer Managed Space:

  • With Storage Type SAP HANA Database (Disk and In-Memory) -> I believe physical storage will be in SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database on which the Datasphere tenant itself relies on.
  • When it comes to Storage Type SAP HANA Data Lake Files:
    • Where are the Data Lake Files behind the Local Table(file) physically stored?
      • In the Object Store?
        • If yes - What kind of Object Store is used?
          • SAP Managed Object Store (File Container)?
          • External Object Store (Azure Blob Storage / Azure Data Lake, AWS S3 bucket, Google Cloud Storage bucket)
      • In the SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake Files (service component) of the SAP HAHA Cloud underlying SAP Datasphere tenant?

Further, in BDC context.

  • Let's say we activated a Data Package from BDC Cockpit, APRS starts pushing data to target HANA Data Lake Files i.e. SAP BDC Foundational services (FOS) layer.
    • Again, where are these Data Lake Files physically stored?

https://help.sap.com/docs/hana-cloud-data-lake/welcome-guide/sap-hana-cloud-data-lake-terminology

https://help.sap.com/docs/object-store/object-store-service-on-sap-btp/what-is-object-store

 

Really appreciate any input helping me to clarify these topics.

Kind regards!

entry.title: Re: How to Identify and Report GOS Attachments Linked to SAP Business Objects?
entry.content: SRGBTBREL is the main table for GOS attachments. If RELTYPE = 'ATTA', the object has attachments. INSTID_A is just the object key (e.g., FI: company + doc number + year; PO: purchase order number). Transactions like FB03/ME23N just display objects—they don’t store attachments. For reporting, focus on object type, not transaction. There’s no single standard report; most people build a custom report or CDS view from SRGBTBREL.

entry.title: SAP BTP - Integration Advisor - (MIG & MAG) from a CPI Developer Perspective
entry.content:
Hello Hello,

Introduction:

In this blog, I would like to share my hands-on experience using SAP Integration Advisor  based on independent exploration and practical experimentation.

The primary focus will be on Message Implementation Guidelines (MIG) and Mapping Guidelines (MAG) exploring when they should be used, when they should be avoided, and how to apply them correctly in real-world B2B - EDI - integration scenarios.

I will also briefly touch on the technology platform context, specifically SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), with the scope strictly limited to integration-related services. Topics such as analytics, artificial intelligence, automation, and application development are intentionally out of scope for this blog.

At the end of the blog, I will include a set of reference materials that supported my learning journey. That said, the majority of the insights and conclusions shared here are derived from direct, hands-on experience rather than theoretical examples.

Technology Platform:

First, let’s start with the Technology Platform. What does that really mean?

A technology platform is the basic foundation that allows software to run. It is made up of different layers that work together, including infrastructure (hardware, memory, storage, databases), the operating system (Windows, Linux), runtime environments, security and networking, and the software layer itself — such as databases, web applications, mobile apps, and IoT solutions.

In simple terms, a technology platform provides everything needed to build, run, and secure applications.

SAP BTP (SAP Business Technology Platform)

SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) is SAP’s cloud-based platform-as-a-service (PaaS) that enables organizations to extend, integrate, and innovate across SAP and non-SAP systems in a secure and upgrade-safe way.

As mentioned earlier, the image below highlights the four technology pillars supported by SAP BTP. That said, in this blog we will focus only on the integration pillar, specifically SAP Integration Suite.

Platform-as-a-service (PaaS) ?

Cloud services are typically delivered through three main models—IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS—each offering a different level of abstraction and responsibility between the provider and the customer. This flexibility allows businesses to choose the model that best fits their technical and operational needs.

  • IaaS (Infrastructure): SAP HANA Enterprise Cloud, SAP Sovereign Cloud, and RISE with SAP.
  • PaaS (Platform): SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), including SAP Integration Suite, SAP Build, and SAP HANA Cloud.
  • SaaS (Software): SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, SAP Concur, and SAP Fieldglass.

What is SAP Integration Suite?

SAP Integration Suite is SAP’s cloud-based integration platform used to connect SAP and non-SAP systems, both in the cloud and on-premise, in a secure, scalable, and standardized way.

  • Cloud Integration – Core component for end-to-end integrations
  • Integration Advisor – Used mainly for B2B and EDI scenarios
  • API Management – Expose, secure, and manage APIs
  • Open Connectors – Prebuilt connectors for third-party applications
  • Event Mesh - The event-driven backbone 

OK, we’ve already talked about the technology platform, explored SAP BTP, explored the cloud types of service and walked through SAP Integration Suite and its components.

Now comes the most important part of this blog — Integration Advisor. So let’s dive in and start this journey together.

What is SAP Integration Advisor?

SAP Integration Advisor is a capability within SAP Integration Suite, primarily designed for B2B and EDI-based integrations, supporting both inbound and outbound scenarios.

Its main purpose is to help organizations design, standardize, and govern message structures and mappings in a reusable, scalable, and partner-independent manner, enabling consistent and efficient integration across multiple business partners.

Instead of building point-to-point mappings directly in iFlows in SAP Cloud Platform Integration, Integration Advisor introduces a model-driven approach based on:

  • MIG (Message Implementation Guideline) – Defines message type content, select field by field from the message type.
  • MAG (Message Mapping Guideline) – Defines mapping logic of fields.
  • TPM (Trading Partner Management) – Assigns partners and agreements at runtime
    Since this is an exploratory blog, we will not go into TPM in depth and will focus only on its definition.

Roles and Responsibilities: MIG vs. MAG from a SAP CPI Developer Perspective:

One important point to highlight is that a SAP CPI developer should generally not be responsible for creating MIGs (Message Implementation Guidelines).

MIGs define the canonical data structure, including business fields, their semantic meaning, validation rules, and compliance with EDI standards. Creating a MIG requires deep business process knowledge and EDI expertise, typically provided by business analysts, functional consultants, or EDI specialists rather than technical integration developers.

From a SAP CPI developer’s point of view, it is technically possible to work with MIGs only if there is very clear and well-defined mapping documentation between the EDI standard and the SAP business objects. Without strong functional input, the risk of semantic errors is high—even if the technical mapping itself is correct.

MAGs (Mapping Guidelines), on the other hand, are where the actual field-to-field mapping logic is implemented. This activity is comparable to traditional message mapping tasks already familiar to SAP CPI developers. It involves transforming source structures into target structures based on predefined rules, conditions, and conversions.

The Mapping Guidelines (MAGs) are designed to support standardized, declarative mappings and therefore do not support complex transformation logic.

MAGs are implemented using XSLT, which is well-suited for:

  • Straightforward field-to-field mappings
  • Simple value mappings and lookups
  • Basic conditional logic
  • Structural transformations

However, MAGs are not intended for complex business logic, such as:

  • Advanced conditional flows
  • Context XML node control
  • Loop Structures
  • Stateful processing
  • Cross-message correlations
  • Custom algorithms or calculations
  • Dynamic, runtime-driven transformations

This is precisely where a SAP CPI developer should be actively involved, as MAGs require strong technical integration skills, knowledge of SAP data models, and experience with transformation logic.

SAP Processes vs. EDI Standards — A Practical Overview

In SAP B2B integration scenarios, the same business process can be represented by different EDI standards, depending on factors such as industry, geographical region, and trading partner requirements.

For example, a single SAP business process (such as Order-to-Cash or Procure-to-Pay) may be exchanged using different EDI formats across partners. This variability increases complexity and requires a structured approach to mapping and governance.

Below is a simplified overview that illustrates how SAP business processes can be mapped to multiple EDI message formats.

What Integration Advisor Can Generate:

Integration Advisor helps standardize and accelerate B2B integrations by generating:

  • SAP CPI message mappings - in XSLT not as normal Message Mapping
  •  XSDs (XML schemas) - From a SAP CPI developer perspective, it is highly valuable and strongly recommended to extract XSD schemas for both EDI formats and SAP message structures.
  • Technical documentation
  • Reusable mapping templates

These artifacts reduce manual effort and improve consistency across integrations.

When Integration Advisor Makes Sense:

Integration Advisor is a strong fit when you have:

  • Many B2B trading partners - The TPM service that we are not exploring in this blog.
  • Multiple EDI message types - Super valid use for EDI message types.
  • Frequent partner-specific variations
  • Strong governance and compliance requirements
  • Large or distributed integration teams

In these scenarios, Integration Advisor helps enforce standards, improve reuse, and reduce long-term maintenance effort.

When Integration Advisor Is Usually Unnecessary:

Integration Advisor may be overkill when dealing with:

  • One or two trading partners
  • Stable and well-known message formats
  • Simple mappings
  • Heavy use of custom Groovy logic -  (MAGs) are designed to support standardized, declarative mappings and therefore do not support complex transformation logic.
  • Small or fast-paced projects

Business Context: Inbound EDI Integration into SAP

To simplify the explanation, I designed a single high-level diagram that illustrates the end-to-end inbound EDI flow, instead of presenting multiple step-by-step screenshots and low-level technical details.

Integration Advisor Design Approach

In SAP Integration Advisor (IA), the process starts with the definition of Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs).
For an inbound integration scenario, two MIGs are required:

  1. Outbound MIG (from the external partner perspective)
  2. Inbound MIG ( to the SAP system perspective)

Use Case Description:

In this proof-of-concept, I am working with the EDI X12 message type 850 (Purchase Order), version 004010, including the envelope structure. This simulates an external trading partner sending an EDI message into the SAP landscape.

For this purpose, I created the following MIG for the external system:

  • MIG.ORDERPROCESS.X12.850.OUT

On the SAP inbound side, the target system is SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, using the IDoc message type ORDERS05 (related to ORDCHG/ORDERS processing).
Accordingly, I created the inbound MIG:

  • MIG.PROCESSORDERS.IDOC.ORDERS05.IN

Mapping Design (MAG)

After defining both MIGs, the next step is to create the Mapping Guideline (MAG).
The MAG defines the field-level mapping rules between the two message structures:

  • Source: MIG.ORDERPROCESS.X12.850.OUT
  • Target: MIG.PROCESSORDERS.IDOC.ORDERS05.IN

This mapping represents the logical transformation from the EDI Purchase Order format into the SAP IDoc structure required by S/4HANA.

 

Artifacts for SAP Cloud Integration:

Once the MAG is finalized, Integration Advisor generates a ZIP package that can be downloaded.
This package contains all technical artifacts required for implementation in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI), including:

  • XSLT files (mapping logic)
  • XSL files
  • XSD schemas (source and target message structures)

These artifacts are then imported and used directly within the iFlow ( EDI Integration Templates for SAP Integration Advisor ) ensuring consistency between the design-time definition in Integration Advisor and the runtime implementation in CPI.

Considering that this is an exploratory exercise, I will not perform end-to-end testing with an actual sending system and a receiving system.

It is important to mention that you can choose either to download the ZIP file or to directly inject the generated artifacts (XSDs and XSLTs) used by the MAG into SAP Cloud Integration directly from SAP Integration Advisor.

Instead, I made the necessary adjustments within the standard iFlow – EDI Integration Templates for SAP Integration Advisor, and I will use a Content Modifier with the message body containing an EDI Flat File X12 850, version 004010.

The final result will be an IDoc ORDCHG / ORDERS05, based on the simple mapping defined in the MAG – Mapping_MIG.ORDERPROCESS.X12.850.OUT_to_MIG.PROCESSORDERS.IDOC.ORDERS05.IN.

The image below demonstrates the test execution.

To simplify the explanation, the image below illustrates the Outbound MIG based on an EDI Flat File, the Inbound MIG based on an IDoc, and the MAG responsible for performing the field-level transformation between both message structures.

Proposed Scenario: EDI Integration Without Architectural Governance - SAP Integration Advisor

In this scenario, no definition or governance was provided by the SAP Integration Architecture or SAP Solution Architecture teams.
There was no strategic decision to organize or centralize EDI integrations using SAP Integration Advisor.

As a result:

  • No EDI governance model exists
  • No MIGs or MAGs were defined
  • No standardization or reuse of EDI structures
  • Each EDI integration is treated as an isolated, custom implementation

Direct Impact on the SAP CPI Developer:

Due to the lack of architectural definition, the SAP CPI Developer receives the following business requirement directly:

Without SAP Integration Advisor, the developer becomes responsible for:

  • Interpreting the entire X12 850 structure
  • Understanding functional EDI rules (loops, qualifiers, segments)
  • Manually building a complex field-level mapping
  • Managing versioning and future changes
  • Implementing validations, exceptions, and error handling within the iFlow

In practice, architectural and functional responsibilities are shifted to the technical layer.

The image below illustrates this scenario, in which SAP CPI was responsible for the entire end-to-end integration, without guidance or governance from SAP Integration Advisor, and still managed to successfully build the iFlow.

The most concerning part for me was the creation of the Message Mapping. The difference between using a MAG (Mapping Guideline) and building a manual Message Mapping is significant and far more complex, as illustrated in the image below.

It is important to note that MAGs are not intended to handle complex logic, which means each scenario still needs to be analyzed and designed on a case-by-case basis.

 

Conclusion from SAP CPI Developer Explorer:

When properly governed by SAP Integration Architecture or Solution Architecture, SAP Integration Advisor provides strong benefits such as standardization, reuse, naming conventions, version control, and centralized management of EDI integrations. This significantly reduces complexity, risk, and long-term maintenance effort.

It is important to clarify that this governance is not the responsibility of an SAP CPI consultant or developer.
The architect defines standards and governance; the CPI developer implements them.

Without architectural governance, complexity shifts to the technical layer and increases operational risk.

Thank you.

Kind regards,

Viana.

Blogs about the topic:
Integration Advisor: Overview of components for building B2B integration content and further reading
Beginner's Guide to Integration Advisor
Integration Advisor - Key concepts of a Message Implementation Guideline
integration content advisor: Create a customized interface using MIG editor

entry.title: Re: Particular Z* report hangs CI when runs there but not...
entry.content:
This behavior is expected in some landscapes and is usually due to different memory distribution and workload characteristics on CI vs. application servers.

On the CI, dialog processes also handle enqueue, update, background coordination, and message server communication, so a Z report that consumes excessive roll/heap memory (SYSTEM_NO_ROLL) can block shared resources and cause paging at OS level. This explains why the CI appears to “hang” while an app server terminates quickly with a dump.

In your case, the heap parameter distribution is significantly different (especially abap/heap_area_dia, abap/heap_area_nondia, and abap/heaplimit). The CI allows the report to grow longer in heap usage, leading to heavy paging instead of fast termination.

Best practice:

  • Avoid running heavy custom reports on CI

  • Keep memory parameters consistent across instances

  • Ensure Z reports are optimized to fail fast rather than exhaust heap

  • Prefer background/app servers for memory‑intensive programs

That’s why the same report behaves differently on CI vs. APP servers.

entry.title: Re: how to move existing attachments into new external st...
entry.content: Yes, it is possible, but not directly with RSIRPIRL for SOFFDB. Attachments stored in SOFFCONT1 (SAPoffice / SOFFDB) cannot be moved automatically to a Content Server using RSIRPIRL, as this report mainly supports ArchiveLink/KPro repositories. The recommended approach is: Assign a KPro content repository (OAC0) for new attachments. Use RSBCS_REORG to clean up obsolete SAPoffice documents. For existing attachments, use RSGOS_RELOCATE_ATTA (see SAP Note 2293171) or a custom migration program using KPro APIs. Alternatively, use a certified third‑party tool (e.g. OpenText, Gimmal, YAC) for mass migration. SAP does not provide a standard report to fully migrate SOFFCONT1 contents to a Content Server.

entry.title: Re: How to migrate from SAP content server to OPENTEXT?
entry.content:
GOS attachments and their relationships to business objects are stored in table SRGBTBREL.
You can identify attachments using fields like TYPEID_A (Business Object), INSTID_A (Object Key), and RELTYPE (e.g. ATTA for attachments, NOTE for notes).
For content storage details, related SAPoffice tables such as SOOD / SOFM / SOC3 or DMS tables like DRAD (if DMS is used) may be required.

entry.title: Re: Assign and Process Purchase requisition
entry.content:
Hi Dinesh,

Yes, your requirement can be effectively achieved by using Purchasing Groups (EKGRP) as the primary organizational driver. The Purchasing Group identifies the buyer or team responsible for the material, and it allows procurement users to filter and process only the PRs assigned to them.

Recommended Approach

  • Assignment: Use transaction ME57 (Assign and Process Purchase Requisitions). Procurement users can filter by their specific Purchasing Group to claim and convert PRs into Purchase Orders.
  • Governance: Implement a Release Strategy to ensure PRs are approved before conversion.
  • S/4HANA Best Practice: If you are on S/4HANA 2022 or later, I highly recommend using Flexible Workflow for Purchase Requisitions. This allows dynamic routing to specific users based on conditions (like Purchasing Group) directly to their Fiori My Inbox.

Configuration Steps (SPRO)

Requirement SPRO Path / Transaction

Purchasing GroupMaterials Management > Purchasing > Create Purchasing Groups (V_024)
Release CharacteristicsMaterials Management > Purchasing > Purchase Requisition > Release Procedure > Procedure with Classification (CT04)
Release ClassesMaterials Management > Purchasing > Purchase Requisition > Release Procedure > Procedure with Classification (CL02)
Flexible WorkflowFiori App: Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions (App ID: F2705)

I hope this helps clarify your process!

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Massive Update Tax Type and Tax Number Type in Busine...
entry.content:
To perform a massive update of Tax Type (Tax Category) and Tax Number once Business Partners have been created, there are two primary recommended approaches for an On-Premise environment.

Option 1: Standard Mass Maintenance (MDC Framework)

If your system has SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) licensed or the "Mass Processing" features active, you should use the modern Consolidation and Mass Maintenance framework. The legacy MASS transaction is not recommended for Business Partners as it does not handle the tax number table (DFKKBPTAXNUM) efficiently.

  • Transaction: MDC_MASS_DATA_CLIENT (or Fiori App: Start Mass Maintenance - Business Partners).
  • Process: Select the Business Partner object (147) and ensure the Tax Numbers entity is included in the scope.
  • Benefit: It provides a UI-driven wizard to upload Excel files, validate data against standard SAP checks, and activate changes in bulk.

Option 2: Custom ABAP Program (BAPI Approach)

If you do not have MDG or prefer a programmatic solution to automate the logic, you can create a simple ABAP report. This follows the Clean Core strategy by using released SAP APIs instead of direct table updates.

Key Function Modules:

Scenario Function Module
Add new Tax dataBAPI_BUPA_TAX_ADD
Modify existing dataBAPI_BUPA_TAX_CHANGE

Code Snippet Logic:

LOOP AT lt_upload_data INTO ls_data.
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BUPA_TAX_ADD'
    EXPORTING
      businesspartner = ls_data-partner_id
      taxtype         = 'HN1' " Example Tax Type for Honduras
      taxnumber       = ls_data-tax_val
    TABLES
      return          = lt_return.

  IF NOT line_exists( lt_return[ type = 'E' ] ).
    CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT' EXPORTING wait = 'X'.
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.

Considerations

  • Customizing: Ensure the Tax Category (e.g., 'RS') is maintained in transaction BUPA_TAXNUMTYPE before running your update.
  • Electronic Invoicing: Since these fields are required for e-invoicing, using BAPIs is critical because they trigger the necessary validations that a simple UPDATE statement to table DFKKBPTAXNUM would skip.
  • Documentation: Reference the SAP Help Portal on BP Data Transfer for further technical details.

entry.title: SAP Success Factors Integration with Data Lake
entry.content:
There are various ways to Integrate SAP Success factors with Data Lakes (Azure Data Lake, AWS S3, or SAP HANA Cloud LAKE)

 Possible Approaches

  • Native SAP Solutions
  • SAP Datasphere: This is the primary modern tool for connecting SuccessFactors to a data lake. It uses Replication Flows to extract data via OData and push it into targets like Azure Data Lake Storage (ADLS) Gen2 or the integrated SAP HANA Cloud Data Lake.
  • SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration): Formerly known as CPI, this middleware can be used to build custom integration flows that fetch data from SuccessFactors APIs and send it to various cloud storage endpoints. 
  • Third-Party Middleware (Best for Azure/AWS/Snowflake)

Several no-code/low-code tools offer pre-built connectors to simplify the ETL process: 

  • CData Sync: Automates continuous replication from SuccessFactors to Azure Data Lake. It supports CSV, Parquet, and Avro formats.
  • Rivery: A cloud-native ELT platform that extracts SuccessFactors reports and loads them directly into data lakes or warehouses in a few clicks.
  • Boomi: A common middleware for SAP environments that provides a dedicated SuccessFactors connector for complex data transformations before landing in a data lake. 
  1. SuccessFactors Integration Center
  • SFTP Export: You can use the built-in Integration Center within SuccessFactors to schedule CSV or XML file exports to an SFTP server. Many data lakes (like Azure or AWS) can then be configured to automatically ingest files from that SFTP location.

Implementation Steps

  1. Authentication: Configure OAuth 2.0 or Basic Authentication in SuccessFactors Admin Center to allow the integration tool access to APIs.
  2. Schema Mapping: SuccessFactors data is highly relational. Ensure your target data lake has a defined structure (e.g., Delta Lake or Parquet) to handle the nested employee master data.
  3. Governance & Security: Since HR data is sensitive, ensure the data lake has strict role-based access controls (RBAC) that mirror the permissions set in SuccessFactors. 

 

Conclusion

There are multiple ways to establish integration and sync the data between SAP Success Factors and Data Lakes.

 

Thank You

Regards

Vish

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA–Does Leading Ledger 0L Require the Same Fisca...
entry.content:
Hi @suba2605 ,
In SAP S/4HANA all company codes assigned to the leading ledger (0L) must share the same Fiscal Year Variant (FYV) and Posting Period Variant (PPV). This restriction was introduced to ensure consistency in the Universal Journal (ACDOCA) and enable reliable cross-company reporting. The error in FINSC_LEDGER occurs when company codes with mismatched FYVs or PPVs are assigned to 0L, and the correct resolution is to harmonize these settings across all company codes in the leading ledger.

Let me explain you why the restriction in S/4HANA?

Universal Journal (ACDOCA):
In S/4HANA, all financial postings (FI, CO, AA, ML, etc.) are stored in one table (ACDOCA). To maintain consistent period definitions, the system enforces a single FYV and PPV for all company codes in the leading ledger. Otherwise, cross-company transactions would be misaligned (e.g., one company in period 3 while another is in period 4).

Cross-company reporting:
Consolidated reporting requires aligned fiscal calendars. Different FYVs/PPVs would break group-level reporting and cause inconsistencies in period-based KPIs.

Technical simplification:
ECC allowed flexibility because data was split across multiple tables. S/4HANA’s design prioritizes harmonization and simplification over flexibility, reducing reconciliation effort.

To resolving the FINSC_LEDGER Error you have to check following assignments.
Use FINSC_LEDGER to review company codes assigned to 0L. Verify their FYV and PPV settings in OBY6 (company code global parameters). Also you have to harmonize settings. Align all company codes under 0L to the same FYV and PPV. If business requirements demand different fiscal calendars, consider Non-leading ledgers: Assign company codes with different FYVs to separate ledgers. Ledger groups: Use ledger groups for reporting flexibility.

Best practice:
Leading ledger (0L) should represent the group standard fiscal year.
Company-specific deviations should be handled via non-leading ledgers or special ledger configurations

Hope my above explanation is helpful for you.

entry.title: Re: SAP ISU FICA clearing document posting
entry.content:
Hi @Mohammed_Yusuf_ficaconsultant ,
What I understand the c0urrent behavior is, When you clear open items (either manually in FP06 or automatically via FPMA), SAP posts one clearing document that includes all debit and credit items matched in that run. If you have multiple payment items (e.g., 2 credits vs. 2 debits), they all get lumped into a single clearing document.
The client requirement is, each payment line item should generate its own clearing document.

To do this follow options are mentioned below.


Option 1. Custom Clearing Logic (BTE / Enhancement)
Use Business Transaction Events (BTEs) or User Exits in FI-CA/FI to control clearing behavior.

Relevant BTEs:
00002040 (Document Clearing)
00002050 (Payment Lot Posting)

You can enhance the clearing routine so that instead of grouping items, it forces SAP to post one clearing document per payment line.

Option 2. Payment Lot Customization
In Payment Lot Customizing (IMG → Contract Accounts Receivable → Incoming Payments → Payment Lot), check if you can adjust the lot posting rules. Sometimes, splitting logic can be controlled by lot item grouping or posting area rules.

Option 3. Batch Job Splitting
Instead of clearing all items in one FPMA run, configure the background job to process each payment lot item separately. This way, each run generates one clearing document.

Option 4. Alternative: Clearing Control via Posting Area 0210
In FI-CA, posting area 0210 (Clearing) controls how clearing documents are generated. You may need to adjust the clearing variant so that it doesn’t combine multiple items into one document.

Hope one of option can fit to you.

entry.title: SAP SD Plant Rollout – Configuration Scope & Common Pitfalls

entry.title: SAPUI5 Table Selection: SingleToggle vs Custom Single-Selection with Checkboxes
entry.content:
Introduction:

While building a table in SAPUI5, I faced the challenge of allowing users to select only one row at a time, while also ensuring a clean and intuitive interface. This led me to explore two approaches for implementing single-row selection using SingleToggle and a custom single-selection with checkboxes approach.

The goal was simple: Allow users to select only one row at a time. However, I also needed to give them a checkbox interface, which led me to try two solutions.

 

Option 1: Using SingleToggle

SAPUI5 offers a built-in SingleToggle selection mode that works well when you don't need checkboxes and only need to highlight one row at a time.

XML View:
<ui:Table
    id="appointmentTable"
    rows="{globalModel>/uiData/Orders/Appointments}"
    selectionMode="SingleToggle"
    rowSelectionChange=".onAppointmentRowSelectionChange"
    enableColumnReordering="false"
    rowHeight="48"
    columnHeaderHeight="56"
    class="sapUiTinyMarginBottom">
</ui:Table>
How it's works?

  • Only one row can be selected.

  • Clicking the same row again deselects it.

  • No checkboxes; just row highlighting.

 SingleToggle is perfect for simple selection without checkboxes.

 

Option 2: Custom Single Selection with Checkboxes

When users expect checkboxes, but you still want to limit selection to one row, you can use MultiToggle mode combined with a custom event handler.

XML View:
<ui:Table
    id="appointmentTable"
    rows="{globalModel>/uiData/Orders/Appointments}"
    selectionMode="MultiToggle"
    rowSelectionChange=".onAppointmentRowSelectionChange"
    enableColumnReordering="false"
    rowHeight="48"
    columnHeaderHeight="56"
    class="sapUiTinyMarginBottom">
</ui:Table>
Controller Logic:
onAppointmentRowSelectionChange: function (oEvent) {
    this.oAppointmentTable = oEvent.getSource();
    const aSelectedIndices = this.oAppointmentTable.getSelectedIndices();

    if (aSelectedIndices.length > 1) {
        const iLastIndex = oEvent.getParameter("rowIndex");
        this.oAppointmentTable.clearSelection();
        this.oAppointmentTable.addSelectionInterval(iLastIndex, iLastIndex);
    }
}
How it's works?

  • Only one checkbox is selected at a time

  • Shows checkboxes for selection

  • Provides intuitive user experience

This custom solution allows for single selection with checkboxes, giving users a familiar UI while ensuring only one row is selected.

 

Choosing the Right Approach

Use CaseRecommended Option

Simple highlight-only single selectionSingleToggle
Need checkboxes but still restrict to a single selectionCustom handler (as shown above)

 

Concluding Thoughts!

SAPUI5 gives us flexibility for row selection. If we just need single selection without checkboxes, SingleToggle is the way to go. However, if checkboxes are required, the custom handler approach ensures users can only select one row at a time while maintaining a clean UX.

Both solutions are simple to implement and offer clear user interactions. This is how I approached the issue, but if you have any other suggestions or methods for handling this, please feel free to share them here. I would love to learn from your experience too!

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! If you found this helpful, please feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments. Let's keep learning and growing together!

Dear experts, I’m new to blogging, please feel free to correct me if any information is inaccurate.

entry.title: Re: Not able to find /LRN/S4D400_EXERCISE package
entry.content:
This is a very common issue for learners using the SAP BTP ABAP Trial or a personal system instead of the official SAP Learning System Access (LSA).

The package  LRN/S4D400_EXERCISE (and the table /LRN/S4D400_APT inside it) does not exist on the standard public SAP BTP Trial. It is exclusive to the paid/official training systems provided by SAP Learning System Access.

Since you are likely on the free BTP Trial, you cannot "add" this package. Instead, you must manually create your own objects that mimic the missing ones.

The exercise asks you to copy /LRN/S4D400_APT. This is just a simple Flight table. On the BTP Trial, you have an almost identical table available: /DMO/FLIGHT
