entry.title: KPI Tags in SAP Fiori Elements List Report (OData V4) — Beyond Analytical Applications
entry.content:
Introduction

KPI (Key Performance Indicator) tags are commonly associated with analytical applications in SAP Fiori, but did you know you can also implement them in standard non-analytical list report pages?

OData V4 in SAP Fiori elements provides a manifest-based configuration approach that lets you add dynamic, clickable KPI indicators to any list report page—without needing an analytical service.

This blog walks you through the official implementation approach to show how to:

  • Configure KPI tags in manifest.json
  • Create reusable KPI fragments with the macros:KPITag building block
  • Bind dynamic data and handle press events
  • Understand the architecture and design patterns

Why KPI Tags Matter in List Reports

A KPI tag is a compact, clickable indicator that displays:

  • A numerical value (e.g., total cost, contribution amount, order count)
  • A unit or measurement (currency, percentage, days)
  • A visual status (color-coded: Success, Warning, Error, Information)
  • Optional icon and tooltip

In list reports, KPI tags provide at-a-glance insights without cluttering the data table. They're especially valuable for:

  • HR & Benefits applications — Show headcount, enrollment rates, total costs
  • Sales dashboards — Display order counts, revenue, pipeline value
  • Finance reports — Highlight outstanding invoices, approvals pending
  • Operations — Monitor KPIs like availability, efficiency, cycle time

Part 1: Understanding the Two Approaches

Approach 1: Analytical Applications (Analytical List Pages)

  • Requires an analytical data source with aggregated/pre-calculated data
  • Configured via CDS annotations in the backend as well as manifest configuration in UI
  • Example: SAP Analytical List Pages (ALP)
  • Best for: Large-scale data analysis, multi-dimensional analytics, pre-aggregated metrics

Approach 2: OData V4 List Reports (What This Blog Covers)

  • Uses manifest-based configuration + custom XML fragments
  • Works with any non-analytical OData V4 service
  • Configuration entirely in the frontend (manifest.json + UI5 fragments)
  • Fully customizable via UI5 controller extensions
  • Best for: Standard enterprise list reports, responsive dashboards, interactive KPIs

This approach is ideal for developers who want simplicity and flexibility without backend annotation complexity.

Part 2: Setting Up KPI Tags in manifest.json

KPI tags are registered in the manifest under the keyPerformanceIndicators section within the list report target:

"targets": {
  "mainPage": {
    "type": "Component",
    "id": "Default",
    "name": "sap.fe.templates.ListReport",
    "options": {
      "settings": {
        "contextPath": "/RootEntity",
        "variantManagement": "None",
        "initialLoad": true,
        "keyPerformanceIndicators": {
          "myKPITag": {
            "template": "sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.CustomKPITag"
          },
          "myKPIWithPress": {
            "template": "sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.CustomKPITagWithPress"
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Key Points:

  • keyPerformanceIndicators — Container for all KPI definitions in this page

  • myKPITag, myKPIWithPress — Unique identifiers for each KPI block (you can name these anything)

  • template — Path to the fragment file (can be in your app namespace or SAP's example path)

You can define multiple KPI blocks by adding more entries. Each entry corresponds to one fragment template.

Part 3: Building KPI Fragments with the macros:KPITag Building Block

SAP recommends using the KPI building block (macros:KPITag) to maintain consistent design with analytical applications.

Simple KPI Fragment (Static Values)

<core:FragmentDefinition 
  xmlns="sap.m" 
  xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" 
  xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros">
  
  <macros:KPITag
    number="0"
    unit="Days"
    status="Error"
    showIcon="true"
    press=".extension.sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.LRExtend.onKPIPressed"
  />
  
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Properties Reference

Property

Type

Purpose

Example

number

Number

The KPI value to display

0, 5000, 15.5

unit

String

Unit or measurement label

"Days", "USD", "%"

status

String

Visual indicator color

"Success", "Warning", "Error", "Information"

showIcon

Boolean

Display status icon

true / false

press

String

Event handler for click

.extension.[controller.path].onKPIPressed

tooltip

String

Hover text

"Total Orders"

visible

Boolean

Conditional visibility

true / false

enabled

Boolean

Enable/disable interaction

true / false

Part 4: Handling KPI Press Events

When a KPI tag is clicked, the press handler in your controller extension is triggered:

Step 1: Define the Controller Extension

In your manifest, register a controller extension for the ListReport:

"sap.ui5": {
  "extends": {
    "extensions": {
      "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
        "sap.fe.templates.ListReport.ListReportController": {
          "controllerName": "your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Step 2: Implement the Press Handler

In your ListReportExt.controller.js:

sap.ui.define(
  ["sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension"],
  function(ControllerExtension) {
    return ControllerExtension.extend(
      "your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt",
      {
        onKPIPressed: function(oEvent) {
          const oSource = oEvent.getSource();
          const sKPIId = oSource.getId();
          
          sap.m.MessageToast.show("KPI " + sKPIId + " was pressed!");
          
          // Add custom logic here:
          // - Filter the table
          // - Navigate to detail page
          // - Show breakdown analysis
          // - Trigger backend action
        }
      }
    );
  }
);

Step 3: Register in Fragment

Reference the handler in your fragment's press event:

<macros:KPITag
  number="0"
  unit="Days"
  status="Error"
  press=".extension.your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt.onKPIPressed"
/>

Part 5: Building Multi-KPI Layouts with FlexBox

For a professional dashboard with multiple KPIs, use FlexBox for responsive layout:

<core:FragmentDefinition 
  xmlns="sap.m" 
  xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" 
  xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros">
  <FlexBox 
    direction="Row"
    wrap="Wrap"
    gap="2rem"
    justifyContent="SpaceAround"
    alignItems="Start">
    
    <!-- KPI 1 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Total Orders" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="1234"
        unit="Orders"
        status="Success"
      />
    </VBox>
    <!-- KPI 2 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Revenue" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="523000"
        unit="USD"
        status="Information"
      />
    </VBox>
    <!-- KPI 3 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Pending Approvals" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="47"
        unit="Items"
        status="Warning"
      />
    </VBox>
  </FlexBox>
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Part 6: Binding Data Models

To make KPIs dynamic (not just static values), you need to bind them to data models.

Creating a KPI Data Model

In your ListReportExt controller:

onInit: function() {
  const oKPIModel = new sap.ui.model.json.JSONModel({
    totalOrders: 1234,
    revenue: 523000,
    pendingApprovals: 47,
    costStatus: "Success"
  });
  
  this.getView().setModel(oKPIModel, "kpiModel");
}

Binding in Fragment

<macros:KPITag
  number="{kpiModel>/totalOrders}"
  unit="Orders"
  status="{kpiModel>/costStatus}"
/>

Updating Data Dynamically

fetchKPIData: function() {
  const oModel = this.getView().getModel(); // OData model
  
  oModel.read("/RootEntity", {
    success: (oData) => {
      const oKPIModel = this.getView().getModel("kpiModel");
      oKPIModel.setData({
        totalOrders: oData.OrderCount,
        revenue: oData.TotalRevenue,
        pendingApprovals: oData.ApprovalCount
      });
    }
  });
}

Part 7: Best Practices and Design Patterns

1. Responsive Design

  • Use wrap="Wrap" in FlexBox for mobile compatibility
  • Test on different screen sizes
  • Consider hiding KPIs on very small screens if needed

2. Status Color Coding

Use status colors to convey meaning:

  • Success (Green) — All good, target met
  • Warning (Orange) — Attention needed, approaching limit
  • Error (Red) — Critical, action required
  • Information (Blue) — Neutral, FYI

3. Meaningful Units

  • Always include a unit if applicable (currency, count, percentage, time)

4. Interactive Press Handlers

Make KPIs actionable:

  • Filter the list to show related records

  • Open a breakdown popover with summary data

5. Loading States

Use busy indicators while fetching data:

<FlexBox busy="{kpiModel>/loading}">
  <macros:KPITag number="{kpiModel>/value}" />
</FlexBox>

Part 8: Troubleshooting Common Issues

Issue

Solution

KPI tags not showing

Verify manifest template path is correct; ensure fragment file exists at that location

Static values work, but binding doesn't

Check model name matches in binding (e.g., {kpiModel>/...}); verify model is set before fragment renders

Press event not firing

Ensure press handler includes .extension. prefix; verify controller extension is registered in manifest

Mobile layout broken

Add wrap="Wrap" to FlexBox; test responsive breakpoints; use sap.ui.Device for responsive logic

Blank KPI in production

Check backend OData service returns required fields; add error handling for failed reads

Part 9: Comparison — Analytical List Pages vs. OData V4 Manifest-Based KPIs

Configuration

CDS annotations + Manifest Configuration

Manifest Configuration only

Data Source

Analytical data models with aggregation

Any OData V4 service

Setup Complexity

High (requires analytical CDS views)

Low (JSON config + fragment)

Customization

Framework-driven

Full UI5 flexibility

Performance

Optimized for large aggregations

Good for summary metrics

Event Handling

Predefined navigation & analytics

Custom controller logic

Best For

Enterprise analytics dashboards

Standard business apps with KPI summaries

Learning Curve

Steep (analytics concepts)

Gentle (standard UI5 patterns)

Part 10: Live Example Reference

SAP provides a working example in the Flexible Programming Model Explorer:

Custom KPI Tags in List Report — FPM Explorer

This interactive demo shows:

  • Static KPI tags

  • KPI tags with press events

  • Various status types and layouts
  • Responsive behavior

Recommended: Clone this example and adapt it to your use case.

Part 11: What's Next? — Custom Charts & KPI Visualization

Coming in Next Blog:

In this blog, we learned how to add interactive KPI tags to any list report page. But what happens when users click on a KPI?

In the next blog, we'll explore:

  1. Building Custom Charts — Visualize KPI data using chart libraries
  2. Mapping KPI Data to Chart Models — Prepare and transform data from your OData service
  3. Opening Charts in Dialogs/Popovers — Display detailed analysis when KPI is clicked
  4. Multi-dimensional Visualizations — Show data breakdowns by different dimensions
  5. Dynamic Chart Updates — Refresh visualizations based on filter selections

Imagine clicking on a "Revenue" KPI and instantly seeing a pie chart breakdown by product category, or a bar chart comparing revenue across regions. That's what we'll build next!

Resources

  • SAP Fiori Elements Documentation — Creating Key Performance Indicators
  • macros:KPITag API Reference
  • FPM Explorer — Custom KPI Tags Example
  • SAP Community — Fiori Elements
  • Analytical List Page Documentation

Summary

KPI tags are not limited to analytical applications. By leveraging OData V4's manifest-based configuration and SAP UI5's flexible architecture, you can add powerful, clickable KPI indicators to any list report page.

Key Takeaways:

  • KPI tags work with standard (non-analytical) OData V4 services

  • Configuration is simple: manifest entry + fragment + optional controller logic

  • Full customization via UI5 — binding, styling, event handling

  • Responsive design built-in via FlexBox

  • Press handlers enable analysis and interaction

Whether you're building HR dashboards, sales pipelines, financial reports, or operational monitors, KPI tags can elevate user experience by providing instant insights at a glance.

Start experimenting with the FPM Explorer example today, and stay tuned for our next blog on custom charts and KPI visualization!

Questions or feedback? Drop a comment below—I'd love to hear about your KPI use cases!

entry.title: Re: SAP BP best practice: payer vs bill to when member VA...
entry.content:
Hey,

 

 

1. Core Principle (Most Important)

In SAP SD/FI, VAT liability and invoice legality must follow the VAT-liable legal entity, not the entity that pays.

Whoever’s VAT number must appear on the invoice should normally be the payer for tax determination purposes.

The paying agent is economically settling the invoice, but is not VAT-liable.

This drives almost all configuration decisions.

2. Recommended BP Role Model (High Level)

- Member = Payer (VAT-liable party)

- Paying Agent = Bill-to / Alternative Payer

Not the other way around.

Why:

  • VAT determination in SD is driven by payer at sales-org level (as you stated)

  • Invoice must legally belong to the member

  • Credit notes must legally be raised to the member

  • VAT reporting must reference the member

The paying agent is acting on behalf of the member, not replacing them as VAT debtor.

3. BP Role Assignment (Concrete)

Member (VAT-liable)

BP Role Purpose
Sold-to (SP)Contractual member
Payer (PY)VAT determination & legal invoice party
Bill-to (optional)If invoice header needs member name
FI CustomerReceives invoice & credit memo

Key settings

  • Member’s VAT registration number maintained in:

    • BP → Tax Numbers

    • Assigned to correct country & tax category

  • This VAT number will:

    • Drive VAT determination

    • Print on invoice

    • Appear on credit notes

Paying Agent

BP Role Purpose
Bill-to (BP)Invoice recipient (C/O)
Alternative PayerCash settlement
FI CustomerPayment handling

Key settings

  • Paying agent does NOT drive VAT

  • VAT number can exist for information, but:

    • Must NOT be used for tax determination

  • Address can be printed as C/O line

4. Invoice Layout (C/O Requirement)

This is a form issue, not a master-data misuse issue.

Correct approach

  • Invoice header:

    • Legal party: Member

    • VAT number: Member

  • Address block:

    • “C/O Paying Agent”

  • SAP forms (Adobe / SmartForms):

    • Use Bill-to address

    • Prefix with “C/O”

    • Reference Sold-to / Payer for VAT & legal text

This avoids distorting the BP model just to satisfy formatting.

5. VAT Number Maintenance (Critical)

Best Practice

Entity VAT Number Usage
MemberMandatoryTax determination + invoice
Paying AgentOptionalInformational only

Do NOT

  • Put paying agent VAT number on payer role

  • Override tax country to force tax logic

If VAT is driven by payer + sales org, the payer must be the member.

6. Credit Notes & Payment to Another BP

This is standard SAP functionality.

Credit Note Issued To Member

  • Credit memo posted to:

    • Member AR account

  • VAT reversed correctly (member VAT number)

Payment Made to Paying Agent

Use Alternative Payee functionality.

Option A – Alternative Payee (Recommended)

In BP → FI Customer → Payment Transactions:

  • Assign Alternative Payee = Paying Agent

  • Enable:

    • “Alternative payee allowed”

  • Result:

    • Credit memo stays on member AR

    • Payment is made to paying agent’s bank

This is fully standard SAP FI.

Option B – One-Time or Clearing Account (Not Recommended)

Sometimes used, but:

  • Breaks audit trail

  • Complicates AR reconciliation

  • Avoid unless regulatory reasons

7. Bank Master Data (Best Practice)

Paying Agent

  • Maintain bank account(s) here

  • Used for:

    • Incoming payments

    • Outgoing credit note payments

Member

  • No bank account required if they never receive cash directly

Payment flow

Credit Memo → Member AR Payment Run → Paying Agent bank account

Linked via Alternative Payee.

8. Standard SAP Patterns You Can Reference

SAP Concepts Used

  • Business Partner roles (SP / BP / PY)

  • VAT determination via payer

  • Alternative Payee (FI-AR)

  • C/O addressing via invoice form

  • Credit memo posting to original payer

SAP Notes / Keywords to Search

(Exact note numbers vary by release)

  • “Alternative Payee in Accounts Receivable”

  • “VAT determination payer sales organization”

  • “SD invoice C/O address”

  • “Agent payer scenario SAP SD FI”

9. Summary Recommendation

Topic Recommendation
PayerMember
VAT numberMember only for tax
Paying agent roleBill-to + Alternative Payee
Invoice layoutMember legal entity, Paying Agent as C/O
Credit notesPosted to Member
PaymentTo Paying Agent bank via Alternative Payee
CustomizationMinimal – mostly standard

 

 

Best,

Edrilan Berisha
